Jason Simon, the guitarist and voice behind meaty neo-psychedelic stoner rockers Dead Meadow, has more in his record collection than old Black Sabbath and Blue Cheer records. His eponymous solo debut, a bare-bones collection of acoustic dirges and poignant country-tinged folk tunes, seems cut from the same era, but with a far gentler hand. The appropriately titled opener, Ã¢â‚¬Å“LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Begin,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ will be the litmus test for most listeners, as its languid, dreamlike cadence provides the foundation for whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s to come. SimonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s skillful blend of Black Rebel Motorcycle Club's balladry, 16 Horsepower's torrential brimstone, Bert Jansch's intricate guitar work, and Bonnie "Prince" Billy's loose delivery works best on apocalyptic tumbleweed epics like Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Dust Does BlowÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“A House Up on the Hill,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ both of which manage to sound visceral and urgent despite their molasses-fueled trajectory. Armed with nothing but his reedy voice, guitar, and the occasional harmonium, bulbul tarang (Indian banjo), and backing vocal, Simon makes a big sound out of very little, and much like contemporaries Faun Fables, Espers, and Woven Hand, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a sound thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s both achingly familiar and alarmingly wild.
